name: shane Jones
comment info: Girls consistently earn better grades than they’re seen as teacher’s favorites, suggesting that the rise in female teachers doesn’t disadvantage boys — they get equal attention. The issue may instead be that boys pay less attention to female teachers due to social norms about interacting with women.I wonder if girls have always been stronger academically but were once held back by limited access or encouragement. And if girls now outperform boys in school, why doesn’t that lead to greater leadership or success after graduation?Anthropologically, this shift could reduce coupling: high-achieving women may avoid partnering with men who can’t match their ambitions or still expect traditional domestic roles — as seen in a number of Asian countries. In a more macro scale there's a national safety issue at hand as well. So what did once motivate boys? That's the question. Was it teacher support, peer competition, social expectations, or the clear link between academic success and future prosperity — a link that feels weaker today? Could it be all of the above which boys now satisfy through playing video games? Maybe we need a similar survey of 60, 70, and 80 year-olds to compare, and/or a survey of single gendered schools to see if there's any difference there. Title: Girls do better in school. So what?

replies.name: G
replies.comment info: @shane Jones You make some good points about girls doing better in school but not always ending up more successful later. I also like your question about what used to motivate boys and what’s changed now. Your ideas about comparing different generations or schools make sense and would be interesting to see.

1. I notice that for each question asked, the highest percentage of those surveyed thought that both genders excelled equally, the second-highest percentage refers to those who thought girls excel more, and the least percentage thought boys excel more. name: Andy
comment info:
1. I notice a strong perception that girls excel academically, with 55% of teenagers saying girls get better grades compared to only 42% who believe it is equal. I also notice that for most categories, the majority of teens see boys and girls as "about equal," but where an imbalance is perceived, it often favors girls. For instance, in "More leader roles," 27% see girls in more roles versus only 16% who see boys in more. The one area where a perceived imbalance favors boys is in being "Teacher favorites," where 16% see boys as favorites compared to only 6% for girls.
    
    2. I wonder why there is a perception that boys are more likely to be teacher's favorites despite girls being seen as getting better grades. I also wonder how these perceptions have changed over time and what specific actions or behaviors led to these results. Finally, I wonder if these perceptions influence the career choices and academic confidence of the teenagers themselves.
    
    3. This graph can impact a community by highlighting persistent gender stereotypes in schools. For students, believing that one gender is inherently better at academics or leadership could limit their own aspirations or create unfair expectations. For educators and parents, it serves as a call to examine their own biases and classroom practices to ensure they are fostering a truly equitable environment where all students feel they can excel and speak up.
    
    4. The Grade Gap: Teens See Girls Leading in School, But Boys as Teacher Favorites

name: Gary
comment info:
Gender: it's there and (almost half the time) it matters
    
    On average, more than half the time gender appears to make no difference, which seems to make plenty of sense. Gender does not inherently change personality. A second observation is that of the gender differences noted (again a statistical minority of the subjects), there was a larger variance for girls. 
    
    I wonder if this is principally due to the various gender roles taught to girls in such a misogynistic society such as ours. Some girls are taught to stand by while others taught to stand up. Meanwhile, it has appeared that boys are generally taught without such extremes.
    
    To myself, it's a reminder that gender doesn't define anyone, but still can influence our experiences, particularly when we are children.

replies.comment info:
Hi @gabriela g,
    Great comments. You mention something very important. The sample size (number of responses included in the graph) has the ability to affect the graph itself. At the same time, if we have a representative sample, meaning the opinions expressed reflect the opinions of all U.S. teenagers, then, the sample size does not matter as much. The real goal of collecting a survey is to appropriately represent the opinions of all individuals you are interested in. In many ways, that is less influenced by how many are surveyed than how representative their opinions are. Keep noticing and wondering!
